headline: Parliament Debates Palestine Recognition Amid Fierce Economic Clashes and New 'Boy Racer' Bill
summary: Parliament was dominated by an urgent debate on whether New Zealand should recognise a State of Palestine, sparking emotional exchanges over the nation's foreign policy stance. The heated debate followed a fiery Question Time where the Government and Opposition clashed over the economy, job losses, and the cost of living. The day also saw the introduction of new legislation aimed at cracking down on antisocial driving with tougher penalties, including vehicle forfeiture.

topicSummaries.topic: Urgent Debate on Palestinian Statehood Dominates Parliament
topicSummaries.content: An urgent debate, prompted by Labour's Peeni Henare, centred on the Government's decision to wait until September to consider recognising a State of Palestine. Labour, the Greens, and Te Pāti Māori strongly condemned the delay, citing the severe humanitarian crisis in Gaza and arguing New Zealand was falling behind its international partners. Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters defended the Government's position, stating it was a complex issue requiring a careful and judicious process, and criticised Labour for not taking the same action during its years in power. The debate saw Green Party Co-leader Chlöe Swarbrick ejected from the House after refusing to apologise for calling some government MPs "spineless".

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Peeni Henare (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: We asked the question of the Government: how many more people will suffer and how many more people will die because of the Government dragging its heels on such an important matter? We are being left behind. New Zealand is being left behind on the international stage.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Winston Peters (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: For the Labour Party's benefit, they had 15 years to recognise Palestine statehood... Did they do it in those six years? No. So, please, answer this question—why on earth now do they think they have the answers when they didn't have them then?

topicSummaries.topic: PM Luxon and Opposition Clash Over Economy and Job Losses
topicSummaries.content: Question Time featured tense exchanges over the state of the economy, with Opposition Leader Chris Hipkins repeatedly challenging Prime Minister Christopher Luxon on job losses and the cost of living. Hipkins questioned the Prime Minister on Finance Minister Nicola Willis's comment that newly unemployed people "shouldn't take it personally". Luxon defended the remark's context, attributing the economic hardship and job losses to the previous Labour government's spending, which he dubbed "The Sixty-six Billion Dollar Man's" legacy. The Opposition argued the government was out of touch and making things worse, while the Prime Minister maintained his government was focused on driving economic growth.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: So why doesn't he think people who have lost their jobs should take it personally?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (National)
keyExchanges.quote: I think people having lost their jobs is an incredibly sad thing. The reason it's happened is because of his administration, because he actually didn't run the economy well, and when you don't run the economy well, you end up causing pain and suffering for low and middle income New Zealanders; and that's exactly what he did.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Introduces 'Boy Racer' Bill With Vehicle Forfeiture Penalties
topicSummaries.content: Transport Minister Chris Bishop introduced the Antisocial Road Use Legislation Amendment Bill, aimed at cracking down on illegal street racing, intimidating convoys, and other disruptive driving. The bill's central measure is a presumptive sentence of vehicle forfeiture and destruction after just one offence, a significant strengthening of the current three-strikes policy. Labour supported the bill to the select committee stage, while the Greens opposed it, with MP Tamatha Paul arguing it was based on the "myth of deterrence" and would disproportionately harm young Māori men.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (National)
keyExchanges.quote: In most cases, courts will be required to order the vehicle be forfeited or destroyed after just one offence. This sends a really powerful message: if you use your car to intimidate and endanger others, you risk losing it.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tamatha Paul (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: The people who will be impacted by this bill, make no mistakes, are young Māori men. In 2023, Māori made-up around half of those charged with fleeing police. And it's not about the behaviour; it's about systemic bias...

topicSummaries.topic: Education Minister Announces Major Overhaul of NCEA System
topicSummaries.content: Education Minister Erica Stanford announced a proposal to replace the NCEA qualification with a new system. Key changes include replacing NCEA Level 1 with a "foundational skills award", introducing new Level 2 and 3 certificates requiring students to pass at least four subjects, and returning to marks out of 100 with grades like A, B, or C. Stanford argued the reforms were necessary to address issues with NCEA being overly flexible and inconsistent, citing hundreds of thousands of blank exam papers and a lack of teacher confidence in the system as evidence of its failure.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Erica Stanford (National)
keyExchanges.quote: More than 250,000 exam papers were left blank, students are more than twice as likely to get an Excellence grade if it's marked internally rather than externally, and 60 percent of teachers don't believe that the new NCEA is a reliable measure of student knowledge and skill. Doing nothing in the face of all this is not an option.

keyExchanges.speaker: Carl Bates (National)
keyExchanges.quote: What feedback has she received from parents?

topicSummaries.topic: Controversial Late-Night Amendments to Resource Management Bill Debated
topicSummaries.content: During the committee stage debate on the Resource Management (Consenting and Other System Changes) Amendment Bill, the Government introduced a substantial last-minute amendment paper that had not undergone public select committee scrutiny. The most contentious change enables regional councils to permit discharges of contaminants that could render freshwater unsuitable for consumption by farm animals. The Government defended the move, with Minister Chris Bishop stating it was an urgent request from Waikato Regional Council to prevent over 2,500 farms from needing new resource consents. Labour and the Greens strongly opposed the change, arguing it was a major step backwards for freshwater protection.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Damien O'Connor (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: I think most farmers around the country would be horrified to think that that legislation is being changed to allow, I would suggest, a small minority of farmers to do this, when, in fact, they have been proud of actually spending millions and millions of dollars to not allow this to happen.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (National)
keyExchanges.quote: The Government is not going to put itself in a position where 2,500 farms require resource consent for something that they do not require resource consent for right now. That is the short point. We are not prepared to do that.

conclusion: The day's proceedings were defined by a sharp divide between the Government's legislative and economic agenda at home and the Opposition's urgent calls for humanitarian leadership on the world stage.
